title-group.article-title: Consequences of chemical novelty: Field performance of the cardenolide-producing crucifer Erysimum cheiranthoides under herbivore attack and heterospecific competition

list-item.p: Plants in the Brassicaceae produce glucosinolates as potent defences against generalist herbivores, but many specialists have evolved the ability to tolerate or even deactivate these compounds. As a possible co-evolutionary response to attack by specialists, plants in the genus Erysimum gained the ability to produce novel cardenolide defences in addition to glucosinolates.

We grew the dually defended E. cheiranthoides side-by-side with the phenologically similar Brassica nigra in agricultural fields surrounded by other Brassicaceae crops. Over the course of two field seasons, we monitored focal plants to characterise their associated herbivore community, and we quantified herbivore damage and measured plant growth. In the second year, we additionally attempted to manipulate herbivore density and plant competition to identify direct and indirect effects on plant fitness.

Both plant species were attacked by a diverse community of specialist herbivores, likely already present on the surrounding Brassicaceae crops. Most herbivores strongly favoured B. nigra, reaching higher densities and causing intense damage that largely suppressed growth of these plants. A similar community of herbivores attacked E. cheiranthoides, but at much lower densities that caused little damage and did not impact plant growth.

In accordance with differential susceptibilities to herbivores, herbivore removal benefitted B. nigra by reducing damage and increasing plant growth, while it had no positive effect on E. cheiranthoides. In fact, herbivore removal had an indirect negative effect on E. cheiranthoides plants growing in conspecific pairs, as they suffered from increased competition by otherwise herbivore-suppressed B. nigra.

Synthesis: Our results agree with a successful escape of E. cheiranthoides from herbivory, as even though plants are still attacked when herbivores are abundant, these herbivores cause little damage and cause no reduction in fitness. However, the escape from herbivory has likely come at loss of competitive ability when herbivore pressure is low, which would explain why despite its key innovation, E. cheiranthoides has been unable to gain dominance in any plant community until now.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In nature, plants are constantly threatened by herbivores, which consume a significant proportion of plant biomass across ecosystems and cause substantial yield losses in agriculture (Johnson, 2011). To protect their limited resources, plants have evolved multiple layers of defence, including physical barriers and chemical defences (War et al., 2012). Chemical compounds in particular play a central role in plant-herbivore interactions, as they can shape the community of herbivores that attack a plant, and in turn are shaped by herbivore-imposed selection (Agrawal, Hastings, et al., 2012; Züst et al., 2012). As a result of reciprocal adaptations between plants and their herbivores, many plants have evolved a vast diversity of toxic, repellent, or antinutritive compounds (Speed et al., 2015).

Resistance traits of plants, including chemical defences, require a significant investment of energy and resources by the plant. For example, production of defensive glucosinolate compounds by plants in the Brassicaceae has been estimated to consume 15% of a plant’s total photosynthetic energy (Bekaert et al., 2012). Defence investments therefore represent a substantial cost for plants, both by decreasing resource allocation to other plant functions (direct or allocation costs, Herms & Mattson, 1992; Züst & Agrawal, 2017), and by indirectly decreasing plant fitness through altered interactions with other species (ecological costs, Strauss et al., 2002). Importantly, both costs and benefits of defence are context dependent, and even direct costs may vary depending on the biotic and abiotic environment. For example, the growth-differentiation balance (GDH) hypothesis predicts a physiological trade-off between faster growth and higher defence levels (Herms & Mattson, 1992), yet rapid growth is primarily essential during plant establishment in highly competitive environments (Züst et al., 2011), while costs may be lower under different conditions. Similarly, high defence investments should only be beneficial in the presence of herbivores susceptible to that defence, while a lack of susceptible herbivores should favour less defended plants (Simms & Rausher, 1987).

The interplay between competition, defence, and herbivory has been well-documented in experimental studies (Hambäck & Beckerman, 2003), where the manipulation or exclusion of herbivores commonly results in substantial shifts in defence trait expression and competitive interactions among plants (Mauricio & Rausher, 1997; Züst et al., 2012). Interestingly, natural gains of novel defences may have analogous consequences to artificial herbivore exclusion: following the gain of a potent new defence, plants may at least temporarily escape herbivore-imposed selection, which likely will alter their competitive interactions and may allow plants to colonize new environments (“escape and radiate”, Ehrlich & Raven, 1964).

For example, plants in the order Brassicales evolved potent glucosinolate defences approximately 80 million years ago, with subsequent biosynthetic innovations in defence triggering bouts of speciation (Edger et al., 2015). However, specialist herbivores eventually evolved strategies to disarm and overcome this defence over evolutionary time (Ratzka et al., 2002; Sporer et al., 2021; Wittstock et al., 2004). As a result, extant species of the Brassicaceae are typically attacked by a diverse community of glucosinolate-resistant herbivores (Bidart-Bouzat & Kliebenstein, 2008; Mertens et al., 2021). However, despite this apparent ineffectiveness against specialist herbivores, most Brassicaceae species nonetheless produce a diverse arsenal of glucosinolate defences (Fahey et al., 2001), highlighting the challenges of inferring ancient evolutionary processes from current ecological interactions.

Gradual co-evolutionary adaptations might feasibly mask the processes that initially shaped new resistance traits, thus focusing on traits of recent evolutionary origin may provide a practical means to explore the costs and benefits of plant resistance before specialized antagonists could evolve. In one such example of a recent gain of a novel defence, plants of the genus Erysimum (Brassicaceae) evolved the ability to produce cardenolide compounds within the last 5 million years (Züst et al., 2020). Cardenolides are a potent class of toxins with distinctly different mode of action from glucosinolates (Agrawal, Petschenka, et al., 2012), and consequently at least some glucosinolate-resistant herbivores are completely repelled from Erysimum plants by these compounds (Sachdev-Gupta et al., 1993; Younkin et al., 2024; but see Wang & Züst, 2025). This ‘escape’ from herbivores may have resulted in a recent and rapid radiation in this speciose genus (Züst et al., 2020). Most Erysimum species co-express glucosinolate and cardenolide defences, but while variation in glucosinolates is limited among species and appears to have become fixed within at least some species (T. Züst, unpublished), variation in cardenolides is much more extensive (Züst et al., 2020), and may reflect more diverse selection pressures acting on the novel defence. To the best of our knowledge, no herbivore has evolved specialised resistance to cardenolides in the Erysimum system, and only one cardenolide-specialised seed bug has shifted its host range to include seeds from these plants (Petschenka et al., 2022). The Erysimum system thus offers a unique opportunity for studying the interplay between herbivory, defence, and fitness, before interactions are changed by coevolution.

Here we use the annual plant Erysimum cheiranthoides to characterise the natural community of herbivores that attack this plant in central Europe. We aim to address whether the gain of cardenolides has allowed this plant to escape from herbivory in a natural community, and to understand the selective forces that act on this species in its putative ‘enemy-free space’ (Jeffries & Lawton, 1984). We compared benefits of the novel defence under high herbivore pressure to potential costs of defence under high competition. To this end, we grew the dually defended E. cheiranthoides side-by-side with a phenologically similar Brassicaceae plant (Brassica nigra) over two consecutive years. Plants were grown in fields adjacent to oilseed rape (Brassica napus), which provided a high density of herbivores specialized on Brassicaceae. We monitored herbivore abundance and plant damage for a full growing season in both years. In the second year we included insecticide treatments to manipulate the costs and benefits of differential investments in resistance traits, and evaluated the performance of both plant species under different levels of competition

We hypothesise that due to its novel cardenolide defence, E. cheiranthoides is better defended and damaged less by herbivores, and consequently achieves a higher fitness compared with B. nigra. Secondly, we predict that the dual investment in defence may render E. cheiranthoides competitively inferior to B. nigra when herbivore pressure is low.

sec.title: Plant material
sec.p: Erysimum cheiranthoides is an annual plant that is native to central and northern Europe and parts of Asia (Polatschek, 2010, 2013), where it grows in scattered populations in ruderal habitats. Plants commonly flower from May through September, with peak flowering in June and seed ripening in August to October (Polatschek, 2013; T. Züst, personal observations). For this study, we used a total of 38 accessions of E. cheiranthoides, which were originally collected from locations in western and central Europe, and which we had propagated in a common greenhouse environment for two generations. To contrast patterns of herbivory on E. cheiranthoides to a more typical Brassicaceae plant, we included the annual Brassica nigra as a control. B. nigra is a representative member of the Brassicaceae that is well-liked by many glucosinolate-resistant herbivores, which shares a similar phenology, and which grows at a similar rate and reaches a similar size as E. cheiranthoides under field conditions. Seeds of B. nigra used in this study were originally provided by the Botanical Garden of Krefeld, Germany. For the current study, we focus on species-level patterns between E. cheiranthoides and B. nigra, thus we treat accessions of E. cheiranthoides as equivalent.

Plants for field experiments were sown in late April for transplantation to the field in late May. We soaked seeds of E. cheiranthoides in water and kept them at 4 °C for three days to break dormancy. Three soaked seeds were placed on the soil surface of pots (7 × 7 × 8 cm) filled with a 1:1 mixture of washed sand and peat-based planting substrate (Einheitserde, Patzer Erden GmbH, Germany). Seeds of B. nigra were directly sown into pots without pre-treatment and lightly covered with soil. Pots were covered with transparent plastic hoods for one week to maintain high humidity, and seeds were germinated in a growth chamber (constant light, 23 °C, 60% relative humidity). Seven days after sowing, plants were moved to an open greenhouse and shaded from direct sunlight for continued growth and hardening. In the last week of May, three-week old plants were transplanted into freshly tilled fields at the Swiss federal agricultural research station (Agroscope Reckenholz, Switzerland). Plants were transplanted to the field inside their plastic pot to slow the escape of growing roots and to limit excessive biomass growth in the field. A small set of plants was kept in the greenhouse for an additional week and used for the assessment of leaf traits (trichome density and size) and innate herbivore preference under laboratory conditions (see Supplementary Methods).

sec.title: Experiment 1: 2022 herbivory
sec.p: In 2022, we used a rectangular field site measuring 6 m × 80 m in a SW to NE orientation (Supplementary Figure S1a, 47.4376° N, 8.5268° E), located alongside a larger field of oilseed rape (Brassica napus). On either side of the experimental plot, 1 m-wide buffer strips of a commercial cover crop mixture consisting of Raphanus sativus and Avena strigosa had been sown two months earlier. We divided the experimental plot into ten blocks (5 × 7 m), and in each block we planted 38 E. cheiranthoides and 4 B. nigra plants in a randomized grid pattern, with plants spaced 1 m apart and with a 0.5 m distance to the plot edge on each side. Throughout the experiment, plants were watered as needed, and the surrounding soil was weeded regularly and kept free of other vegetation. Unfortunately, cover strips had to be mowed halfway through the experiment (week 5) to prevent weed seed dispersal.

We closely monitored plants over a period of nine weeks. In weeks 3, 6, and 9, we assessed plant damage by herbivores, and in the six remaining weeks, we recorded the herbivores that were present on each experimental plant. In weeks of herbivore community assessments, we visited each plant once and recorded the type and number of herbivores sitting or feeding on the plant. Herbivores were recorded at species level where visual identification was feasible, and as functional groups otherwise (e.g., flea beetles, weevils). Assessment of all plants was completed over 2-3 subsequent days in each week. In weeks of damage assessment, we visited each plant once to record leaf damage and plant size. We approximated total damage by counting the number of leaves on a plant with visible herbivore damage of any size, and we approximated plant size by counting the total number of leaves, as well as measuring the height of the plant stem from root base to apical meristem. A representative sample of leaves were harvested and analysed to determine nutritional quality of plants throughout the 2022 experiment. Briefly, leaves were frozen on dry ice and later freeze-dried for 48h. Dried leaf material was then ground to a fine powder and extracted for determination of soluble sugars, digestible starch, and total digestible proteins (see Supplementary Methods).

Whole plants were sequentially harvested for biomass, with complete blocks assigned to different harvests. Block 7 was randomly selected for plants to complete development to seed production. Plants in blocks 1-3 were harvested in week 8 to capture early plant biomass, mostly before seed setting. Plants in blocks 4-6 were harvested in week 11, and plants in blocks 8-10 were harvested in week 14. A few plants had stopped vegetative growth and completely ripened their seed earlier, thus, to prevent loss of biomass we harvested these individuals ahead of schedule. For biomass harvesting, we cut the stem of each plant at soil level and placed the entire aboveground biomass in paper bags. Aboveground biomass was dried at 60°C for 48-96 hours and weighed to the nearest gram. Plants in block 7 were dug out of the soil in week 8 and transported back to a greenhouse where we let them finish their development and ripen their seeds. At the onset of seed ripening, each plant was wrapped in a paper bag to prevent seed loss. After harvesting, seeds were separated from vegetative biomass, biomass was dried and weighed, and seed mass was weighed separately for each plant in this block. Finally, we counted and weighed a subset of 100 seeds for each plant to determine average seed size.

sec.title: Experiment 2: 2023 herbivory and herbivore exclusion
sec.p: Based on the results of the 2022 field experiment, we set up a modified field experiment in 2023 with added treatments of plant competition and herbivore suppression. To test for the effect of plant-plant competition, a subset of E. cheiranthoides plants was grown together with a B. nigra plant in the same 7 x 7 x 8 cm pot. To reduce herbivore loads, half of all plants (individual and competing) were additionally treated with weekly applications of lambda-cyhalothrin (Kendo® Gold, Maag Gardens, Switzerland), a non-systemic pyrethroid insecticide.

In 2023, we used a different rectangular field site measuring 4 m × 66 m in a W to E orientation (Supplementary Figure S1b, 47.4284° N, 8.5232° E), again located alongside a larger field of oilseed rape (Brassica napus). On either side of the experimental plot, 1.5 m-wide buffer strips of the same cover crop mixture had been sown one week prior to transplanting, which were maintained throughout the experiment. We divided the experimental plot into six blocks (3 × 7 m). For blocks 1, 2, 5, and 6, we planted 36 individual E. cheiranthoides and 4 B. nigra plants each in a stratified random grid pattern, with plants spaced 1 m apart and with a 0.5 m distance to the plot edge on each side. For blocks 3 and 4, we planted 40 pairs of E. cheiranthoides and B. nigra plants each, with each pair spaced apart from the next by 1 m (Supplementary Figure S1b). Starting at transplanting, we applied weekly sprays of lambda-cyhalothrin (15 mg/L water) to all plants in blocks 2, 4, and 6, completely wetting all leaf surfaces. We maintained spraying for seven consecutive weeks, increasing the total volume sprayed as plants were growing larger, from approximately 30 mL per plant in the first three weeks up to 150 mL per plant by week 7. Plants in blocks 1, 3, and 5 were sprayed with an equivalent amount of water.

Herbivore community assessments were carried out as before (weeks 1, 2, 4, 5, 7, 8), but we modified our damage assessment (weeks 3, 6, 9) to distinguishing leaves with high (leaves with more than 75% of area damaged) and low damage. With damage assessments, we also measured plant height and the total number of leaves. However, total leaf counts had high levels of observer bias for older (and therefore larger) plants in 2022, thus for weeks 6 and 9, we instead measured plant diameter and branch number. We additionally counted the total number of leaves on 20 randomly selected plants in weeks 6 and 9, and from this subset generated a predictive linear model of total leaf number as a function of plant height, diameter, branch number, assessment week and observer. We then used this model to predict the total number of leaves for all remaining plants. In the 2023 field experiment, all plants were harvested in week 10. We cut plants at soil level and placed the entire aboveground biomass in paper bags, followed by drying at 60°C for 48-96 hours and weighing to the nearest gram.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: The current study is focused on differences between E. cheiranthoides and B. nigra, while variation among E. cheiranthoides accessions will be presented elsewhere. For the 2022 field experiment, we use herbivore community, damage, and plant size data from all 40 B. nigra plants and 40 neighbouring E. cheiranthoides plants. Neighbours were selected randomly out of the maximum of four immediate neighbours for each B. nigra plant (Supplementary Figure S1a). For the smaller 2023 field experiment, we use data from all 16 individual B. nigra plants and 32 randomly selected neighbouring individual E. cheiranthoides plants. Two E. cheiranthoides neighbours were selected for this dataset to avoid issues with small sample sizes (Supplementary Figure S1b). We also included data from all 80 plant pairs in the competition treatment. All analyses were performed in the statistical software R v.4.3.1 (R Core Team, 2023).

sec.title: Herbivore community composition and phenology
sec.p: We summarized herbivore communities by comparing mean total herbivore abundances across entire seasons between plant species. For the 2023 herbivore data, we performed separate principal component analyses (PCAs) for E. cheiranthoides and B. nigra to evaluate similarity in herbivore communities among insecticide and competition treatments (Supplementary Figure S2). As the competition treatment had little effect on herbivore community composition, we only used individual plant data for these analyses.

We first analysed the total number of individuals observed on each plant as a function of plant species, using separate negative-binomial Generalized Linear Models (GLM, function ‘glm.nb’ in the MASS package, (Venables & Ripley, 2002)) for each year, and including insecticide treatment as an explanatory variable for 2023. To examine temporal variation in herbivore presence and abundance, we next employed a series of Generalised Additive Models (GAMs) using the ‘gam’ function in the mgcv package (Wood et al., 2016), fitting separate negative binomial GAMs to total herbivore counts in 2022 and 2023. For the 2022 data, we constructed a full model that included a parametric term of ‘plant species’ and a smoothing term (based on thin plate regression splines) for ‘days in the field’ that was allowed to vary by plant species (i.e. separate smoothers for each plant species). We determined the number of nodes (parameter k in GAM) by subtracting 1 from the total number of weeks insects were observed in the field. To estimate the significance of the parametric term we used the default Wald tests on deviance explained. To evaluate the support for species-specific smoothers, we constructed equivalent models without interaction terms and compared nested models based on BIC. For the 2023 data, we included an additional parametric term of ‘insecticide treatment’ and a modified smoother allowing for an interaction between ‘days in the field’ and all four combinations of ‘plant species’ and ‘insecticide treatment’.

We finally fit a set of models to the individual presence and abundance data for the eight most abundant herbivores in both years. Data from the 2023 insecticide and competition treatments was excluded from this analysis to simplify results. Herbivore abundance was analysed again using negative binomial GAMs, while we also analysed herbivore presence-absence data (i.e., the likelihood of occurrence) using binomial GAMs. To avoid problems with excess zeros, we only included data from weeks in which an herbivore was observed more than once in the dataset, adjusting the number of nodes accordingly for each herbivore (Supplementary Table S2).

sec.title: Plant damage assessments
sec.p: The amount of leaf damage was analysed by fitting a Generalized Linear Mixed-effects Model (GLMM) using the glmer function in the lme4 package (Bates et al., 2015). To account for the paired design of the competition treatment in 2023, we specified ‘neighbourhood group’ as a random effect for all models. In the competition treatment, neighbourhood group refers to individual pots with pairs of plants, whereas in the individual treatment, neighbourhood group refers to three adjacent pots each with a single plant (one B. nigra plant randomly paired with one or two E. cheiranthoides neighbours). For the 2022 field experiment, we used the numbers of damaged and undamaged leaves for each plant as a two-vector dependent variable (i.e., a binomial variable representing the proportion of leaves with insect damage). The model included fixed factors of assessment week, plant species, and their interaction, while individual plant, neighbourhood group, and observer were specified as random effects. To obtain p-values of the fixed effects, we used type III tests implemented in the ‘Anova’ function from the car package (Fox & Weisberg, 2019). Post hoc pairwise comparisons (Tukey’s HSD; α = 0.05) were carried out using the emmeans package (Lenth, 2023).

The amount of leaf damage in the 2023 field experiment was analysed using a similar approach. We analysed the number of highly damaged leaves (leaves with more than 75% of area damaged) and the number of undamaged/low damage leaves as the two-vector dependent variable, with fixed effects of plant species, insecticide treatment, competition treatment, and their interactions. As we did not quantify damage of plants in the competition for week 9, an interaction with assessment week could not be fit, and we instead fit three separate models for weeks 3, 6, and 9, including only random effects of neighbourhood group.

sec.title: Correlations of herbivore observations and plant damage
sec.p: Higher observed herbivore densities are expected to be correlated with higher plant damage, with the caveats that our observations only represent snapshots of the diurnal herbivore community, observed herbivores may not always have been actively feeding on the plants, and not all observed herbivores cause visible damage. To evaluate the relationship between observed herbivores and quantified damage, we combined data of the second damage quantification (week 6) with the abundances of the main herbivores in the two preceding weeks for both years. After centering and scaling of all data, we performed separate PCAs for B. nigra and E. cheiranthoides in 2022, and for B. nigra and E. cheiranthoides in ambient and insecticide-treated conditions in 2023, allowing us to compare correlations between plant damage and abundance of specific herbivore groups.

sec.title: Herbivore impact on plant growth
sec.p: Herbivore numbers dropped substantially following the early mowing of buffer strips in the 2022 field experiment. To test whether this change in herbivore pressure affected plant growth, we quantified plant growth using repeated plant height measurements from weeks 3, 6, and 9 to identify changes in herbivore impact (see Supplementary Methods). In addition to height data, we analysed biomass of plants harvested in weeks 8, 11, and 14 using a linear model (function ‘gls’ in the nlme package, Pinheiro, J. C. et al. 2021) of dry biomass as dependent variable and factors of plant species, harvest week, and their interaction as explanatory variables. Model fit was improved by allowing for separate variances for each harvest week (function ‘varIdent’ in the nlme package). Post hoc pairwise comparisons were carried out using emmeans.

sec.title: Effects of herbivory and competition on plant biomass
sec.p: We explicitly manipulated herbivore densities by insecticide applications in the 2023 field experiment and analysed plant biomass of plants harvested after 10 weeks using a linear mixed-effects model (function ‘lme’ in the nlme package). Dry biomass was fit as a function of plant species, insecticide treatment, competition treatment, and their interactions as fixed effects, and neighbourhood group as random effect. Model fit was improved by allowing for separate variances for each combination of plant species and insecticide treatment (function ‘varIdent’ in the nlme package). Post hoc pairwise comparisons for both models were carried out using emmeans.

sec.title: Herbivore community composition and phenology
sec.p: We observed 14 different herbivores in 2022, with eight out of the nine most abundant herbivores occurring in substantially higher numbers on B. nigra than on E. cheiranthoides (Supplementary Table S1). Total herbivore abundance reached a peak in the fourth week, followed by a decline in the second half of the experiment (Figure 1a). This decline coincided with the removal of the buffer strips on each side of the experimental plot. We modelled herbivore abundance through time using a generalised additive model (GAM) and found a strong main effect of plant species (X2 = 435.30, df = 1, p<0.001), reflecting the overall difference in abundance. Model comparison also revealed support for a plant-specific relationship of total herbivore abundance through time (Figure 1a, Supplementary Table S2).

Individual herbivore species differed substantially in arrival and persistence time (Figure 1b), and even though herbivores generally were co-occurring, temporal dynamics significantly differed between plant species (Supplementary Figures S3, S4). Using individual GAMs for presence and abundance data of the eight most abundant herbivores, we found significant main effects of plant species, support for plant-specific temporal relationships (i.e., plant-specific smoothers in GAMs), or both for all herbivores (Supplementary Table S3). While results differed in magnitude and significance by herbivore, we generally found a higher likelihood of herbivore occurrence, higher herbivore abundance, and longer herbivore persistence on B. nigra compared to E. cheiranthoides. The largest exception to this pattern were the crucifer shield bugs or cabbage bugs (adult Eurydema ornata, E. oleracea, and their larvae), which occurred at similar frequencies on both plants (Supplementary Table S1), and at least during peak herbivore abundance, had a higher likelihood of occurrence on E. cheiranthoides (Supplementary Figure S3).

The observed herbivore community in 2023 was very similar to 2022, except for three low-abundance species that were only observed in 2022. Again, seven out of the eight most abundant herbivores were less abundant on E. cheiranthoides (Supplementary Table S1). As the buffer strips remained until the end of the experiment in this experiment, herbivores persisted for longer and we observed no pronounced decline in total abundance (Figure 1c). Surprisingly, the insecticide treatment in 2023 did not reduce the total observed number of herbivores (Figure 1d), but instead increased the observed number of aphids, pollen beetles, and flea beetles (Supplementary Table S1). Modelling temporal dynamics in total herbivore abundance through time, we found strong support for main effects of plant species (X2 = 127.33, df = 1, p<0.001) and insecticide treatment (X2 = 31.33, df = 1, p<0.001), but model comparison revealed no support for separate temporal relationships for either plant species or insecticide treatment (Supplementary Table S2).

Presence and abundance of individual herbivores also differed by plant species in 2023 (Supplementary Figures S5, S6), with significant main effects of plant species, support for plant-specific temporal relationships, or both for all species (Supplementary Table S3). Aphids and flea beetles persisted for much longer in 2023, likely relying on buffer strips for population maintenance. As in 2022, total abundance of crucifer shield bugs did not differ between B. nigra and E. cheiranthoides (Supplementary Table S1), and we found weak evidence for a higher abundance of this herbivore on E. cheiranthoides towards the end of the 2023 field experiment (Supplementary Figure S6, Table S3).

sec.title: Plant damage
sec.p: Mirroring the results in herbivore abundance, leaf damage on B. nigra was substantially higher than on E. cheiranthoides in the 2022 field experiment (Figure 2, Supplementary Table S4). Damage to B. nigra was almost complete with virtually no leaf left undamaged, while less than 20% of leaves were damaged on E. cheiranthoides. Damage marginally increased on E. cheiranthoides by week 6 (week 3 vs. 6: z-ratio = -2.11, p = 0.088), before dropping considerably in week 9 for both species (Figure 2).

In the 2023 field experiment, quantified leaf damage on B. nigra plants exposed to ambient herbivory was again almost complete (i.e., all leaves had some damage), thus, to avoid issues with zero variance in the smaller dataset, we analysed the proportion of heavily damaged leaves (leaves with more than 75% area damaged). Quantified damage was still substantially higher on B. nigra compared to E. cheiranthoides (Figure 3, Supplementary Table S4). Insecticide treatment strongly reduced damage on E. cheiranthoides plants in weeks 3 (ambient vs. sprayed: z-ratio = 6.36, p < 0.001) and 6 (ambient vs. sprayed: z-ratio = 6.13, p < 0.001), while this effect disappeared by week 9 (ambient vs. sprayed: z-ratio = -0.77, p = 0.437). In contrast, insecticide only significantly reduced damage on B. nigra in week 9 (ambient vs. sprayed: z-ratio = 2.47, p = 0.013). Interestingly, while plant-plant competition did not significantly affect damage in week 3 (B. nigra: z-ratio = -1.82, p = 0.070; E. cheiranthoides: z-ratio = -1.16, p = 0.245), by week 6 B. nigra received significantly less damage in the combined competition-insecticide treatment (Figure 3).

Correlation of herbivore abundances in weeks 4 and 5 with plant damage in week 6 revealed that in the 2022 field experiment, leaf damage on B. nigra was most closely correlated with abundances of P. xylostella (Supplementary Figure S7a), while damage on E. cheiranthoides was correlated with abundances of the crucifer shield bug (Supplementary Figure S7b). In the 2023 field experiment, patterns under ambient herbivory were similar, with abundances of P. xylostella and crucifer shield bugs being among the herbivores most correlated with leaf damage on B. nigra and E. cheiranthoides, respectively (Supplementary Figure S7c-d). Insecticide application changed this relationship, with abundances of most observed herbivores varying independently of damage for B. nigra (Supplementary Figure S7e), and aphids (causing no visual damage) being most correlated with damage for E. cheiranthoides (Supplementary Figure S7f). Interestingly, pollen beetles (Brassicogethes aeneus) were associated with leaf damage for both species in most PCAs, despite not being typical leaf-chewing herbivores.

sec.title: Plant traits and innate herbivore preference
sec.p: The two plant species used in this experiment differ in a wide range of other traits besides cardenolide production. Nutritional traits quantified in the 2022 field experiment showed consistent but modest differences between the two species (see Supplementary Results, Figure S8). In contrast, trichome density and size varied substantially, with leaves of E. cheiranthoides being densely covered in small trichomes on both sides, while B. nigra primarily expressed larger trichomes along leaf veins on the underside of its leaves (see Supplementary Results, Figure S9). We further compared the role of leaf trait differences on innate herbivore preference using cut leaf disc choice assays under laboratory conditions, allowing us to exclude more complex traits such as plant size or leaf shape. Of the four tested Brassicaceae herbivores (two of which we also observed feeding in the field), each significantly preferred B. nigra over E. cheiranthoides (Supplementary Figure S10). Interestingly, this preference was least pronounced for E. ornata, mirroring the weaker preference for B. nigra of this herbivore in the field.

sec.title: Plant growth and competition
sec.p: To better understand herbivore impact on plants, we modelled plant growth in the 2022 field experiment using sequential measurements of stem height. We found strong differences between height growth of B. nigra and E. cheiranthoides (Figure 4a), with E. cheiranthoides reaching the inflection point of a logistic growth function after 29 days, while B. nigra reached this point only after 56 days (Supplementary Table S5). During the first growth interval (weeks 3-6, high herbivore abundance), B. nigra plants only grew 0.31 (0.27-0.36, 95% confidence interval) cm day-1, compared to E. cheiranthoides growing more than 5 times faster by this point (1.74 [1.53-1.93] cm day-1). Growth of B. nigra only increased towards the end of the experiment when herbivore numbers decreased, and by the midpoint of the second growth interval (weeks 6-9, low herbivore abundance) the order was reversed, with B. nigra growing 1.30 (1.11-1.51) cm day-1 and E. cheiranthoides only growing 0.86 (0.75-0.95) cm day-1.

The patterns in height growth of plants in the 2022 field experiment directly translated into differences in aboveground biomass (Figure 4b). In the first subset of plants harvested after eight weeks, B. nigra had significantly lower biomass compared to E. cheiranthoides (pairwise linear contrast: t = -4.33, df =22, p < 0.001). Mirroring the increased height growth of B. nigra in the second half of the experiment, these differences had disappeared by week 11 (t = -0.43, df = 21, p = 0.676) and 14 (t = -0.019, df = 17, p = 0.985).

Based on the strong impacts of herbivores on plant biomass we observed in 2022, we explicitly manipulated herbivore pressure and competitive environment in the 2023 field experiment. For single plants under ambient herbivore pressure, biomass of B. nigra plants after 10 weeks of growth was close to zero, while E. cheiranthoides plants could grow seemingly unimpaired (Figure 5). Even though application of insecticide did not remove herbivores (Figure 1c-d) and only partially reduced observed damage on B. nigra (Figure 3), insecticide-treated B. nigra plants grew better and reached a higher biomass (pairwise linear contrast: t = -3.37, df = 80, p = 0.006). In comparison, E. cheiranthoides gained no equivalent benefit from insecticide application (t = -1.05, df = 80, p = 0.723).

Growing in intense competition with E. cheiranthoides had little effect on B. nigra biomass, which again suffered heavily under ambient herbivory, but benefitted from insecticide applications (Figure 5). Biomass of E. cheiranthoides growing in competition with B. nigra under ambient herbivory was likewise largely unchanged, but application of insecticide substantially reduced E. cheiranthoides biomass (t = 2.72, df = 80, p = 0.039), likely as a direct result of increased competition from less-attacked B. nigra plants. A reduction in biomass has direct fitness consequences for an annual plant such as E. cheiranthoides, and we found a strong positive correlation between aboveground biomass and seed production among the plants we left to complete seed production in 2022 (Supplementary Figure S11).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The dually defended E. cheiranthoides was attacked by substantially fewer herbivores than its Brassicaceae relative B. nigra in two years of field observations. Herbivores caused severe damage to leaves of B. nigra, and in consequence, growth of B. nigra was almost completely suppressed by herbivory when insect herbivores were abundant. In contrast, even during peak abundance, the limited herbivore damage on E. cheiranthoides had no apparent impact on plant growth, matching a successful escape from herbivore-imposed selection. Experimental manipulation of herbivore abundances and plant-plant competition not only revealed a lack of a negative impact of herbivore selection on E. cheiranthoides, but even a benefit of herbivore pressure under conditions of intense competition. If herbivore suppression of B. nigra was removed, increased competition from B. nigra reduced growth of E. cheiranthoides by half, suggesting that the defensive superiority of the dually defended E. cheiranthoides is paired with a weak competitive ability.

Herbivores attacking B. nigra and E. cheiranthoides were mostly Brassicaceae specialists with known tolerance of glucosinolate defences. These herbivores were almost certainly present in high numbers in the surrounding Brassicacaea crops and cover strips and ‘spilled over’ onto experimental plants (associational susceptibility, Barbosa et al., 2009). This effect was made clear by the sharp decline in herbivore numbers on experimental plants when cover strips had to be mowed prematurely in 2022. While we intentionally selected a Brassicaceae-dominated environment to ensure high specialist herbivore pressures, other field studies commonly find specialist insects to be the dominant herbivores of Brassicaceae plants as well (Bidart-Bouzat & Kliebenstein, 2008; Mertens et al., 2021), likely because the glucosinolate defence acts as potent filter against many generalist herbivores (but see Zalucki et al., 2021).

The suite of herbivores we observed is representative of the main Brassicaceae herbivores in central Europe (Mertens et al., 2021), but interestingly, we never observed larvae of the cabbage white butterfly (Pieris rapae) feeding on experimental plants, despite adult butterflies being present in the environment in both field seasons (K. Wang & T. Züst, personal observations). The larvae of P. rapae are major herbivores of many Brassicaceae plants but they are highly susceptible to the cardenolides in E. cheiranthoides (Sachdev-Gupta et al., 1993). While the lack of P. rapae larvae on E. cheiranthoides is thus expected, their absence on B. nigra is more surprising, and it is possible that B. nigra plants gained associational resistance against this herbivore at the field scale (Atsatt & O’Dowd, 1976; Barbosa et al., 2009) by being surrounded by E. cheiranthoides neighbours. Interestingly, we also found additional evidence for associational resistance gained by B. nigra in the competition treatment, with insecticide-treated plants paired with E. cheiranthoides receiving the lowest amounts of damage overall. Competition has been shown to increase defence expression in some plant species (Lankau & Kliebenstein, 2009), thus B. nigra may have benefitted from growing next to E. cheiranthoides while suppressing its growth at the same time.

Specialist herbivores of the Brassicaceae plants commonly have low specialization among different Brassicaceae species (Mertens et al., 2021). Of the herbivores we observed, most consistently preferred B. nigra over E. cheiranthoides, regardless of taxonomic group or feeding guild (e.g., caterpillars, flea beetles, aphids). The only exception to this pattern were the crucifer shield bugs (Eurydema ornata, E. oleracea, and their larvae), which occurred on both plant species at similar abundances, and at least over select periods, were more likely to occur on E. cheiranthoides. Several species of Eurydema are known to feed on different Erysimum species (Gómez, 2005), and both E. ornata and E. oleracea are commonly found feeding on natural E. cheiranthoides plants (T. Züst, personal observations). Despite this frequent association, Eurydema bugs showed a slight preference for B. nigra under laboratory conditions, and the species remain broadly generalised herbivores of many Brassicaeae species (Piersanti et al., 2020). It thus remains currently unclear whether Eurydema bugs are in the process of specializing on Erysimum, or whether they simply favour certain traits shared by Erysimum and other Brassicaceae plants.

Among the specialist herbivores in our field surveys, most showed reduced total abundances on E. cheiranthoides, but none exhibited complete avoidance of the dually defended plant. Importantly, we did not distinguish between perching and feeding herbivores in our observations, and several of the observed herbivores are highly mobile (e.g., pollen beetles, flea beetles). It is thus feasible that herbivores were constantly arriving on E. cheiranthoides, but did not settle after initial sampling of the plant. High mobility may also explain the higher numbers of observed herbivores on insecticide-treated plants in 2023. Pyrethroid insecticides are toxic upon contact but have a relatively low environmental persistence (Ripley et al., 2001), thus weekly applications likely knocked down herbivore numbers and reduced plant damage, but the resulting increase in plant quality may have subsequently attracted higher numbers of mobile (less damaging) herbivores. Correlations between herbivore abundances and plant damage supported this explanation, as under ambient herbivore conditions, plant damage on B. nigra and E. cheiranthoides was best correlated with P. xylostella and E. ornata abundance as two major damaging herbivores, respectively. In insecticide-treated plants these correlations disappeared, and damage was either not strongly correlated with any herbivore on B. nigra or correlated with non-damaging aphids on E. cheiranthoides.

Although the comparison of B. nigra and E. cheiranthoides in our study highlights differences in herbivore-imposed selection, it can only provide partial insights into the causal role of cardenolides in plant defence. Many other traits, such as foliar nutrients, trichomes and leaf architecture, also vary between these species. Our measurements revealed only modest differences in foliar nutrients between B. nigra and E. cheiranthoides, and total protein content as a key resource for herbivores did not differ between plant species for most of the experiment. Differences in trichomes were more substantial between species, and trichomes often play a role in plant defence against insects (Levin, 1973; Sato et al., 2019), yet their role and relative importance for E. cheiranthoides defence remain to be elucidated. Structural traits such as plant height, size, or shape could also have affected herbivore colonization (Strauss et al., 2015) but such differences are perhaps less likely to explain the observed patterns in our study, given the similarities in plant size, similar apparency of plants in a weeded bare soil environment, and consistent preference for B. nigra of four Brassicaceae herbivores in leaf disc choice assays. Overall, the large observed differences in herbivore preference are unlikely to be caused by the relatively modest differences in nutritional traits or plant shape. Cardenolides thus remain one of the most distinctive traits between the two species, although the additional importance of trichomes and perhaps other unmeasured traits cannot be ruled out at this point.

A direct causal role of cardenolides for defence of E. cheiranthoides was recently demonstrated by Younkin et al. (2024), who used a newly developed CRISPR/Cas9 knockout line of E. cheiranthoides with abolished cardenolide production to evaluate herbivore responses in the laboratory and field. In their study, certain specialist herbivores, including Pieris rapae, exhibited increased feeding on knockout plants while completely avoiding cardenolide-producing wildtype plants. Other herbivores, including flea beetles and aphids, showed no consistent differences in feeding on knockout or wildtype plants (Younkin et al., 2024), and an apparent lack of a cardenolide effect was recently reported for P. xylostella as well (Wang & Züst, 2025). These findings suggest a more nuanced role of cardenolides in the defence of E. cheiranthoides, with the novel compounds acting as highly effective qualitative defences against some herbivores, and as less effective quantitative defences – or even ineffective compounds – against others. To understand the full impact of cardenolide variation on herbivore damage, a future in-depth analysis of intraspecific variation among natural E. cheiranthoides genotypes may prove useful.

While E. cheiranthoides was mostly protected from negative impacts of herbivore feeding, the dual production of glucosinolate and cardenolide defences likely represents a major allocation cost for this species. Trade-offs between resistance traits and growth or other plant functions are expected to be ubiquitous (Züst & Agrawal, 2017), yet they may sometimes be masked by variation in other traits (Koricheva et al., 2004). The production of glucosinolates (in Arabidopsis thaliana) and cardenolides (in Asclepias syriaca) have both been shown to reduce growth under some conditions (Züst et al., 2011, 2015). The dual investment required for producing both compounds concurrently thus may simply represent too large of a cost to become masked, and such a cost is the most likely cause for the weak competitive ability of E. cheiranthoides demonstrated in this study. However, despite the substantial costs at lower herbivore abundances, our study clearly demonstrated a benefit of this defensive strategy in other conditions. Damage by herbivores can reduce growth of undefended plants directly by reducing photosynthetically active leaf area and depleting vital plant resources (Machado et al., 2016), or indirectly by inducing plant responses that divert resources away from growth to defence (Attaran et al., 2014; Zangerl et al., 2002), yet E. cheiranthoides experienced neither of these impairments under high herbivore pressure. By preferentially attacking the competitively superior susceptible host plants, herbivores thus benefitted a competitively inferior resistant plants, which would be expected to result in an increase in its frequency over time (Crawley, 1989; Myers & Sarfraz, 2017).

Despite weak competitive ability of E. cheiranthoides (and likely that of its close relatives) in the absence of specialized herbivores, the genus Erysimum has undergone a recent radiation that coincided with the gain of cardenolides (Züst et al., 2020), suggesting that this key innovation facilitated an escape from herbivory and subsequent diversification in enemy-free space. However, E. cheiranthoides, and species in the genus more generally, still mostly occupy marginal habitats that are often devoid of vegetation, rarely forming large populations. Erysimum plants thus appear to lack the ability to become dominant species within a community, despite being better defended than most of their heterospecific neighbours. Further evolutionary change and optimization may perhaps lower costs of defence for these plants in the future (e.g., Karasov et al., 2017). However, an increase in frequency of Erysimum plants may also increase selection pressures for the types of specialized herbivore resistance to evolve that are common in cardenolide-producing plant systems (Dobler et al., 2012; Petschenka et al., 2017), thus continuing the never-ceasing arms race between plants and their herbivores.

In conclusion, the gain of a novel defence appears to have allowed Erysimum plants to escape herbivore-imposed selection, if not herbivory entirely. However, the costs required to maintain this ‘enemy-free space’ are so substantial that plants can only thrive under conditions where competitors are absent, or where they are suppressed by strong herbivory. As these specific conditions are rare, Erysimum is currently confined to survive in marginal habitats, yet changing environmental conditions might well favour this unusually well-defended plant in the future.
